likely_uncovered_areas_or_ambiguities: Detailed sub-guides under Identity Engine and Classic Engine (for example, every factor type, policy option, and app template) weren’t exhaustively reviewed; many fine-grained behaviors and exceptions remain unanalysed.

Customer Identity Cloud / Auth0 technical documentation is only referenced via links and not deeply read; CIAM capabilities are described mainly from the Okta Customer Identity marketing page and IAM concepts.
Full REST API surface (users, groups, apps, policies, hooks, logs, etc.) was not enumerated endpoint-by-endpoint; only high-level categories and example operations are covered.
Admin Console UI behavior, tenant lifecycle (org creation, deletion, migration), and data residency options are not fully mapped from documentation.
Newer capabilities like Cross App Access (XAA) and broader AI-agent features are only covered at press-release / blog level; protocol and data model specifics are unclear.

Some products mentioned in navigation, such as Secure Partner Access, API Access Management, Secure Identity Integrations, and certain training/roadmap features, were not independently opened or analysed.
Classic Engine vs Identity Engine behavioral differences are only visible at high level; per-feature differences, migration paths, and edge-case compatibility are not fully captured.
assumptions_made: Okta orgs are treated as multi-tenant identity domains with logically isolated identity data, even though the internal multi-tenancy model and data isolation implementation weren’t explicitly detailed.

Core IAM capabilities like user, group, and app management, SSO, MFA, and lifecycle management are assumed to be available across both Classic and Identity Engine, with Identity Engine adding more granular, flow-based controls.

REST APIs referenced from external examples (e.g., Users, Groups, Apps, System Log) are assumed to be current and representative of the main API surface, despite not reading each dedicated reference page.
Customer Identity capabilities are assumed to be primarily backed by the Auth0 platform where the docs link to Auth0 developer resources, though only Okta-side overview material was read.

Capabilities like event-based automation, System Log streaming, and security integration via shared signals are assumed to behave like typical webhook/event-driven systems, based on high-level descriptions but without protocol-level detail.
Okta Privileged Access (OPA) is assumed to expand privileged access management beyond the earlier Advanced Server Access product, but only the ASA docs were analysed in depth.

Lifecycle Management actions that provision or deprovision accounts, groups, and entitlements across connected systems.
Identity Governance actions such as campaign creation, bulk revoke decisions, and entitlement policy changes.
Workflows flows that perform high-privilege tasks (e.g., assigning admin roles, resetting MFA, disabling users).
Access Gateway administrative tasks including deploying nodes, configuring HA, and onboarding on-prem applications.
Advanced Server Access configuration of teams, projects, and access rules that govern privileged server access.
Aerial operations that grant time-bound admin access to managed orgs.
Identity Threat Protection policy changes that define when sessions are terminated or users are quarantined.
ISPM configuration of connectors and the acceptance or dismissal of findings that drive remediation.
user_configurable_logic: Sign-on and authentication policies in Identity Engine and Classic Engine, including MFA, device assurance, and contextual access rules.
Lifecycle Management group rules and entitlement policies defining automatic app and role assignments.
Identity Governance SOD rules, campaign scopes, access request types, and routing logic.
Workflows flows defined graphically using events, conditions, and actions, including helper and delegated flows.
Device Access policies controlling desktop MFA behavior, password sync, recovery flows, and device logout.
Identity Threat Protection risk policies mapping risk changes to adaptive actions (MFA prompts, logouts, group changes).
auth_and_identity_behaviours: Support for multiple authentication protocols (OIDC, OAuth 2.0, SAML, WS-Fed) and flows (Auth Code + PKCE, Interaction Code, Client Credentials, etc.).
Phishing-resistant authentication via Okta FastPass and device posture evaluation.
Multifactor Authentication across numerous factors including Okta Verify push/OTP, with risk-based enforcement.
Federated SSO with external IdPs (enterprise and social) and support for B2B and B2C access patterns.
Self-service capabilities for registration, password reset, and factor management, particularly in CIAM scenarios.
Zero Trust-aligned behaviors like continuous session risk evaluation (ITP), device logout, and least-privilege enforcement (ISPM + Identity Governance).
logging_and_audit_behaviours: Comprehensive System Log capturing authentication events, admin activity, provisioning operations, governance decisions, and security detections.
Defined event types and query options allowing fine-grained filtering for monitoring and incident response.
Identity Governance-specific System Log events for campaigns, access requests, and entitlements changes.
Workflows execution history that logs flow runs, inputs/outputs, and errors.
ITP and ISPM dashboards and reports that summarize detections and responses but are ultimately backed by stored events.
Support for exporting data to external SIEM and analytics tools via APIs.
failure_modes: Misconfigured sign-on or MFA policies can lock out users or weaken authentication, depending on error paths and fallbacks.
Provisioning and deprovisioning failures or misconfigurations can leave orphaned accounts or prematurely remove critical access.
Workflows with bugs or mis-specified logic can propagate incorrect changes quickly across systems.
Identity Governance campaign design flaws (e.g., missed scopes, reviewer overload) can leave access unreviewed or rubber-stamped.
Access Gateway or ASA outages or misconfigurations can block access to critical apps or servers or, conversely, expose them if bypassed.
